timeline.message:
Allow cycles

Cycle detection is limited to the suite engine launching other suite engines.
We're using the configuration parameters to smuggle in the parent suite id
for each launching request.

Forbid cycles

Cycle detection is limited to the suite engine launching other suite engines.
We're using the configuration parameters to smuggle in the parent suite id
for each launching request.

timeline.bodyText: Consider explicitly disabling the discovery of launcher-discovery listeners via SPI when introduced by #2457.
timeline.author: mpkorstanje

replies.bodyText: We can keep this enabled. While we try to hide that a suite is discovering and executing tests using the junit platform internally, we don't need to hide that launcher discovery is started multiple times.
replies.author: mpkorstanje

timeline.message:
Implement junit-platform-suite-engine #2416

Implements a test engine that allows declarative execution of test suites using
the `@Suite` annotation.

Internally the Suite Engine uses the JUnit Platform Launcher. The engine works
by mapping the `TestIdentifier` used by the launcher to `TestDescriptor` used
by the engine during discovery and execution.

```
package org.junit.platform.suite;

import org.junit.platform.suite.api.SelectPackages;

@suite
@SelectPackages("org.junit.suite.testcases")
class SelectPackageSuite {

}
```

Is equivalent to:

```
import org.junit.platform.engine.discovery.DiscoverySelectors;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.Launcher;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.LauncherDiscoveryRequest;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.core.LauncherDiscoveryRequestBuilder;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.core.LauncherFactory;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Launcher launcher = LauncherFactory.create();
        LauncherDiscoveryRequest request = LauncherDiscoveryRequestBuilder.request()
                .selectors(DiscoverySelectors.selectPackage("org.junit.suite.testcases"))
                .build();
        launcher.execute(request);
    }
}
```

The suite engine converts an annotated class into a discovery request. This
request is executed and the resulting test plan is mapped to a tree of test
descriptors. In essence the tree of test descriptors are a view on the test
plan. So suppose the discovery requests produces this test plan:

```
JUnit Jupiter
|- TestA
||- method1
||- method2
|- TestB
||- method1
||- method2
```

Then that test plan is mapped to a tree of test descriptors like so:

```
SuiteEngine
|- ExampleSuite
||-JUnit Jupiter
|||- TestA
||||- method1
||||- method2
|||- TestB
||||- method1
||||- method2
````

The unique identifiers are remapped by pre-pending the unique identifier of the suite. So:

```
junit-jupiter/TestA/method1() ->  junit-suite/ExampleSuite/junit-jupiter/TestA/method1()
```

Issue: #744

timeline.bodyText: Can we share this with junit-platform-runner?
timeline.author: marcphilipp

replies.bodyText:
While the name might create the impression that it can be used by a user to build requests to discover test suites, it is only a utility that the suite engine uses to create launcher discovery requests to discover the tests in a suite. In essence it maps suite annotations to a launcher discovery request.
Perhaps a better name is in order.
replies.author: mpkorstanje

replies.bodyText: This is exactly what junit-platform-runner does with the annotations, isn't it?
replies.author: marcphilipp

replies.bodyText: Ah I see. It'd be a single class/module. I'll see about extracting that after everything else.
replies.author: mpkorstanje
mpkorstanje

timeline.bodyText: @marcphilipp wdyt? Would it break the expectation of the LauncherDiscoveryListener to provide the executionId rather then the uniqueEngineId?
timeline.author: mpkorstanje

replies.bodyText: Good question. I think we should pass in executionId because otherwise it would be inconsistent with what the engine passes to selectorProcessed and it's documented to be "the unique ID of the engine descriptor". I took a quick look and the internal implementation looked like they don't make any such assumptions.
replies.author: marcphilipp

timeline.bodyText: I'm surpriced that this isn't already use by test kit.
timeline.author: mpkorstanje

replies.bodyText: Good catch! I think this should be done in the EngineDiscoveryOrchestrator constructor instead so we can avoid making it public.
replies.author: marcphilipp

Document the junit platform suite engine

timeline.bodyText:
Both the platform launcher and platform runner only include classes with specific names when no other pattern is provided. In doing so they ignore ExampleTestCase.failingTest which would fail the build. So we have to explicitly configure the include patterns.
I don't think it is a good idea to repeat this feature in the suite engine. It is a "hidden" requirement in addition to the use of the annotations. However I'm also unaware of the rationale for including it in the first place.
What was is reason to only include classes with certain names by default?
timeline.author: mpkorstanje

timeline.bodyText:
Pruning the test engines is necessary because their test descriptors no longer root containers. This results in them being pruned when added as children to the parent engine. However because the LauncherDiscoveryResult is executed as a whole events for these empty test engine are still emitted resulting exceptions when trying to look up these nodes in in the test plan.
I'm not sure where and if I should convey this information.
Pruning here also avoids the need to open up the LauncherDiscoveryResult more.
timeline.author: mpkorstanje

Implement junit-platform-suite-engine

Implements a test engine that allows declarative execution of test suites using
the `@Suite` annotation.

Internally the Suite Engine uses the JUnit Platform Launcher. The engine works
by mapping the `TestIdentifier` used by the launcher to `TestDescriptor` used
by the engine during discovery and execution.

```
package org.junit.platform.suite;

import org.junit.platform.suite.api.SelectPackages;

@Suite
@SelectPackages("org.junit.suite.testcases")
class SelectPackageSuite {

}
```

Is equivalent to:

```
import org.junit.platform.engine.discovery.DiscoverySelectors;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.Launcher;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.LauncherDiscoveryRequest;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.core.LauncherDiscoveryRequestBuilder;
import org.junit.platform.launcher.core.LauncherFactory;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Launcher launcher = LauncherFactory.create();
        LauncherDiscoveryRequest request = LauncherDiscoveryRequestBuilder.request()
                .selectors(DiscoverySelectors.selectPackage("org.junit.suite.testcases"))
                .build();
        launcher.execute(request);
    }
}
```

The suite engine converts an annotated class into a discovery request. This
request is executed and the resulting test plan is mapped to a tree of test
descriptors. In essence the tree of test descriptors are a view on the test
plan. So suppose the discovery requests produces this test plan:

```
JUnit Jupiter
|- TestA
||- method1
||- method2
|- TestB
||- method1
||- method2
```

Then that test plan is mapped to a tree of test descriptors like so:

```
SuiteEngine
|- ExampleSuite
||-JUnit Jupiter
|||- TestA
||||- method1
||||- method2
|||- TestB
||||- method1
||||- method2
````

The unique identifiers are remapped by pre-pending the unique identifier of the suite. So:

```
junit-jupiter/TestA/method1() ->  junit-suite/ExampleSuite/junit-jupiter/TestA/method1()
```

This is starting to look kinda redundant. A suite without selectors doesn't work anyway. Though on the other hand, it would make it harder if multiple suite engines were used in the same project.

SelectDirectories

SelectModules.
